abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Secondary Education
            Project for El Salvador were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: It is important to find a
            balance between decentralizing responsibilities to schools
            while maintaining some under central level. Education
            reforms should be based on long-term goals but have flexible
            implementation strategies so that different administrations
            can embrace them as their own. The involvement of
            non-governmental organizations, agencies, and private
            institutions in the implementation of education services can
            generate efficiencies for the sector.  Good quality distance
            education can greatly contribute to increase access and
            demand for secondary education. Well-targeted scholarships
            are an important tool to improve equity in access to
            education. School-based projects can be a successful
            stimulant to foster student ownership and participation, as
            well as student retention in schools.
